body: @dkm2110 I have addressed your review comments. Thanks!
Should we add a test here to ensure the behavior is not lost by accident ?

@jwang98052  thinking more about this. Doesn't this put more pressure on waitforregistraton since in the same time now all the registrations have to finish. Alternatively, we can change the logic to: If after retries interval none of the nodes (parent, children) are registered then throw error. i.e. retry loop will be reset once a node is found to be registered. Does that make sense?
Looks good, I'll test and merge

Ok, I've made a second pass. Sahna addressed my comments, I am generally OK with the code now.
I think we should merge it once :
- methods `isClosed` and `isClosing` are moved from `AllcoatedEvaluator` to a more appropriate location
-  the code is tested in a cluster 
- the PR logic is checked by an original author of the REEF runtime.

@markusweimer, @motus  Can you please have a look ?

@dkm2110 We need all the parent/children to be registered before continue. 

Original logic is waiting for parent in the timeout period, then waiting for each child.  It may end up to 3 times of timeout time. 

The new logic is in a single time out loop, check all of them.  We have to make sure all are registered. Otherwise, throw exception. 

Yes, the new logic gives more pressure for waiting up time.  If we need longer timeout, we can set longer. But try one then another would make the entire process longer. 

Of cause, after we receive the registration from parent, most possibly children are also registered during this time.

We already have a lot of tests cases in fault tolerant that hit this scenario. Before the change, a lot of Null Reference exception are found in the driver log. After the this change, I can see those Null Reference logs are gone. Behavior and test results are not impacted by the change except the log.
LGTM, will test and merge
Looks good, I've tested it and will merge
I've done a pass. LGTM, overall. However, there are a couple of breaking changes in this PR that need to go through the deprecation process.
Thanks for the thorough code inspection @markusweimer ! I think I've addressed all the issues raised in the review - could you please take another look?

I've done another pass. Some overall comments in addition to the line comments:
- Please merge multiple method overloads using C#'s default values. That way, the whole interface shrinks considerably.
- Consider `Nullable` instead of `Optional`
- This change adds lots of `public` APIs. I left some comments on that, but please do another pass to see what can be made `internal`
@afchung Hi, could you kindly do a pass? This PR is removing an interface that was introduced in one of your PRs.
LGTM, will test and merge
@markusweimer Would there be any other points to address? ðŸ˜ƒ
@markusweimer Thanks for the comments. I have addressed many and left comments on some. Once we converge on those I will submit another.
LGTM, but I have no way of testing. @johnyangk Can you test and merge?
@jwang98052 @motus Please take a look.

`isClosed()` and `isClosing()` are indeed a bit weird in `AllocatedEvaluator`. `.close()` there merely returns the allocation, so the transition from `isClosing()` to `isClosed()` would be instantaneous. What's the use of exposing those APIs?
I've done a pass.
LGTM. Will test and merge
@motus I have done a pass. Overall LGTM.

I moved these problematic methods from `AllocatedEvaluator` to `TaskRepresenter`, because it also has `EvaluatorManager` of the task.
Does it look better?
LGTM - please rename the class and get rid of those unnecessary braces and I'll be happy to test and merge the PR. Thanks!
@motus I addressed your comments, please test and merge. Thanks!

@motus Please remember to add pull request number to commit message before merging as described at https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/REEF/Commit+Messages, so that PR gets closed automatically when it is merged.

@shulmanb You can close this PR now, since it is merged.
@tcNickolas oops, my fault. @shulmanb could you please close the PR? I've already marked JIRA as resolved. Thanks!
LGTM. Will merge.
LGTM. Will test and merge
@motus Addressed comments

I tested `HelloREEFStandalone`, and it passes. I'll merge

Turns out we should be [fine with copying ACM articles onto our website](http://authors.acm.org/main.html):

> Authors can post the accepted, peer-reviewed version prepared by the author-known as the "pre-print"-to the following sites, with a DOI pointer to the Definitive Version of Record in the ACM Digital Library.
> [...]
> On any non-commercial repository or aggregation that does not duplicate ACM tables of contents, i.e., whose patterns of links do not substantially duplicate an ACM-copyrighted volume or issue. Non-commercial repositories are here understood as repositories owned by non-profit organizations that do not charge a fee for accessing deposited articles and that do not sell advertising or otherwise profit from serving articles.

I believe we are covered by that.
@motus Can you please rebase and squash this into a single commit?
We shouldn't merge changes on the Java side that break the .NET side and vice versa. Is there a way for you to shield the changes such that the .NET does still work?

@markusweimer @dkm2110 I've rebased PR against latest master. This week would be a good one to review, since there will be no ongoing changes to this PR (other than addressing comments).

AppVeyor and Travis have some transient failures, good AppVeyor build is at https://ci.appveyor.com/project/tcNickolas/reef/build/229-REEF-1251-t

Do we log detailed execution of these tests somewhere ?  It is nice the tests are randomized, but, if such a test  fails, how should one approach debugging the error ?  AFAIK, tests schedule about 40 alarms at randomized intervals, which might make it tricky to find or even reproduce the root cause.
@tcNickolas @motus Please take a look. It will probably be easier if I will push it myself to the branch-0.15.1.
This pull request is filled against `master`. Shouldn't it be filled against the release branch?

I've started a review. There seem to be a lot of code quality and testing improvements that are orthogonal to the actual IMRU fault tolerance. Can we factor them out into a PR of its own? That way, this review becomes a whole lot less daunting :)

It should. Not sure how to do that, didn't see any knobs to specify that.

Closing since we have not converged on design and what to do

Jenkins fails on:
FATAL: Could not checkout branch-0.15.1 with start point origin/branch-0.15.1
hudson.plugins.git.GitException: Could not checkout branch-0.15.1 with start point origin/branch-0.15.1

Not sure what it means.

I have a few general notes w.r.t. this PR:
- The code tends to overcatch exceptions, usually catching the `Exception`  class directly. Is such overcatching really necessary ?
- When the code logs exceptions, it logs only the runtime type of them via GetType(). Is it sufficient for debugging purposes ?
- In tests, we should probably explain in a comment how we set the expected test values.
- A common source of cascading failures in distributed systems is an attempt to require a lot of resources at once. In this PR, what would happen if an IMRU job with a large number of mappers suddenly loses half of them and then tries to resubmit them all at once ? I believe this case deserves a special test with YARN.
@shulmanb I am running tests on my PC now. Will merge if everything is OK
@shulmanb could you please take a look and merge? @markusweimer and Sergey @zerg-junior have already made a pass. Thanks!

I'm concerned that doing this change limited to Tang can break something in other projects which rely on certain exceptions having certain types. For example, `lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Network\Group\Task\Impl\GroupCommClient.cs` has a `catch (SystemException e)` clause which might be aimed at these exceptions and will stop working if they inherit `Exception` directly. @jwang98052 Could you please comment on this specific case?

What is the scope of [REEF-334](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-334)? If the goal is to make all of REEF.NET build on Linux, not just Tang, we'd have to replace all occurrences of `SystemException` anyways, so I'd suggest updating them all in one PR.
@motus The JIRA is misleading as it implies that only unit tests are change, but you actually change interfaces here.
@motus Done a pass. Please update the JIRA title and I will merge this.

@dkm2110 @markusweimer The reason I'm reluctant to split this PR into several is that it took us several weeks to test this change in multiple clusters, with varying numbers of evaluators etc. Each separate PR needs to be tested separately, some of the changes will not cause reproducible bugs without the new IMRU code, etc. I understand that is PR has grown to be rather daunting :-) But splitting it, re-testing and re-merging it safely is at least equally, if not more, scary. For example, I've introduced at least one problem when re-merging things a couple of weeks ago.

I've addressed smaller comments. @jwang98052 Could you please take a look at the ones which are left?
@shulmanb Thanks for pointing it out! I've updated [REEF-1533](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1533) in JIRA. Please take a look and go ahead with the merge. Thank you!

I uploaded the pdfs. 
@markusweimer , @tcNickolas Can you please have a look ?
@motus Merged. Please close this PR.

@shulmanb I don't see this PR merged at https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=reef.git . That site shows REEF-1539 as the latest commit.

When you merge PR, you should add its number to the commit message, as described in https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/REEF/Commit+Messages . This way the PR will be closed automatically, and it also helps to keep track of relationship between commit and PR it was produced from.
I'd like to merge this and move on to the implementation. Can you please mark all new `public` APIs as `[Unstable]`? That way we can't accidentally release a version of this and be beholden to it.
The links to files work when I generate site locally.
I've done a pass
@markusweimer could you please take a look? Thank you!
LGTM, will test and merge.
LGTM, I'll merge
@tcNickolas the goal is to make all (or as much as possible) of REEF.NET able to run on Linux.
Then please handle all occurrences of `SystemException` in one change to avoid discrepancies between different occurrences.

I agree. We catch SystemException rather than Exception in many places. If we want to change, we should change it cross entire REEF code. Even with that, at the places where we catch SystemException but not Exception in general, if we change catch SystemException to Exception, we might catch exceptions we did not intent to catch. A better way is to search all the places where SystemException is caught and look at case by case. 
Another concern is our client will have the same issue. They use Tang directly in their code.
@markusweimer  I have marked public interfaces and classes unstable and also did a rebase. Please test and merge.

Actually, for my desktop it doesn't fail on C# build and it makes me harder to find the main cause.
I've just tested this PR on my desktop, and the behavior is the same as in AppVeyor: it passes _build_ but fails most functional tests.
When you're running tests on your machine, make sure you clean build before building .NET code, otherwise .NET tests might use old version of Java code and run a different thing than AppVeyor does.

OK, let's keep this PR as one and aim for smaller ones in the future. That said, we should address the review comments before merging it.
I think I've addressed or answered the comments, except for ones which call for separate PRs/major rework of exception handling.
@markusweimer @dkm2110 I have addressed your review comments. Let us know if it is OK for the merge.

@dongjoon-hyun Tests pass on my machines. The changes look fine to me, but I'd like to confirm that the changes regarding to your personal information can be merged with it. I'll merge it once @markusweimer signs off. Thanks!
Thank you, @yunseong . :)

Looking at this again, there are changes to several modules of REEF here. For instance, there are some changes to Tang, Wake and REEF Common. I understand that the changes to IMRU are somewhat atomic, but at least those changes outside the IMRU and Networking packages could be done in separate PRs, right? They seem to fix genuine bugs in those layers that we'd want to highlight in the change log and release notes for 0.16.
LGTM, will test and merge

@markusweimer Yes, they can be done in separate PRs. However, when done separately, they need to be tested separately. They haven't been found with old IMRU code base, so they'd need to be tested with the new code, like we already did. This will take a lot of time and unnecessarily complicate the process of merging the changes back.

If you want to highlight these bugs in release notes, we can create separate JIRAs for them and resolve them with this same PR.

> If you want to highlight these bugs in release notes, we can create separate JIRAs for them and resolve them with this same PR.

+1 that would serve the goal with bounded effort.
